Award.AwardTitle: SHB: Type I (EXP): Collaborative Research: EasySense: Contact-less Physiological Sensing in the Mobile Environment Using Compressive Radio Frequency Probes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The collaborative research project (IIS-1231754, Santosh Kumar, University of Memphis; IIS-1231525, Mustafa al'Absi, University of Minnesota Twin Cities; IIS-1231577, Emre Ertin, Ohio State University) is developing and evaluating a mobile sensor called EasySense that can provide continuous physiological monitoring without skin contact in the field environments using radio frequency (RF) probes. This approach addresses the problem of physiological monitoring today that requires skin contacts such as electrodes for ECG, and hence cannot scale to widespread monitoring of patients and healthy adults for years. The key challenge is to develop high-resolution sensing on low-power mobile platforms that can separate out the weak motion signals of heart and lung, from the gross motion of the body and the sensor. The project is developing theory and design for a compressive ultrawideband (UWB) RF sensor that achieves two orders of magnitude reduction in the required sampling rate to make it feasible to realize in a low-power mobile form factor. EasySense employs dynamic compressive sensing algorithms to improve the quality of sensing through temporal integration of information and employs interference subspace cancelation methods to cancel out motion artifacts using data obtained from accelerometers and gyroscopes. The project is implementing all the needed hardware, firmware, embedded software on the sensor node for sampling, processing, and wireless communication, and mobile phone software for data collection, storage, and visualization. EasySense is evaluated against traditional physiological sensors via lab and field studies on human subjects involving stress and exercise protocols.

By realizing contactless sensing of physiology in the field environment, EasySense will enable long-term physiological monitoring at large-scale that is essential for determining potential causes and early biomarkers of fatal diseases of slow accumulation such as cancer and cardiovascular diseases. In addition to being used widely in health research and practice, EasySense can be used for hands-on demonstration in health education. Information on the project, developed hardware and software design files and code relating to the testbed infrastructure will be accessible in open source form via the project web site (http://www.easysense.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resulted in a novel contactless sensor for monitoring heart and lung motion from scratch, called EasySense. The project had several significant outcomes. First, investigators at Ohio State developed a fully functioning prototype of all-digital, multi input-multi output (MIMO), Ultrawideband (UWB) radar in mobile form factor, operating in 0.5-3.5 GHz band. They designed compressive sampling schemes for making MIMO measurements of the body and associated subspace learning and exploitation techniques for estimation of physiological signals related to heart and lung motion. The developed UWB sensor provides a means to collect rich data set for RF probing of the physiological processes. The developed interference estimation and suppression algorithms are applicable to many radar applications where weak signals of interest to be extracted in the presence of large signals from background sources and clutter.

 

Second, several units of EasySense were manufactured and sent to University of Minnesota where lab studies were conducted with 45 participants who wore both EasySense and a hospital grade wall-powered sensing system called BioPac. The goal of this study where participants completed stress sessions consisting of public speaking, mental arithmetic, and cold pressor, was to evaluate the accuracy of interbeat interval of the heart and breathing patterns captured by EasySense in comparison with BioPac when both heart and lungs are modulated due to stressors.

 

Third, University of Memphis worked on developing and improving computational models for detecting human behaviors from physiological sensor data. Four articles were published in ACM UbiComp. The first article described a refined model for inferring stress from ECG and respiration that was validated on two independent data sets that is currently regarded as a gold standard in the field. The second article describes a new method we developed to infer smoking using respiration and inertial sensors worn on wrists (e.g., in a smartwatch). Both the models are implemented on the mobile phones and are being used in field studies with 1,000 participants in six field studies. The Memphis team also developed a computational model to infer craving during smoking abstinence from physiological sensors. Finally, the Memphis team developed a computational model to detect momentary speaking episodes (at the fine granularity of each breath cycle) from respiration measurements that achieves similar performance in the field environment as audio based speech detection. Each of these models can work with data collected by EasySense once the data collected from the lab study are fully analyzed to establish the accuracy of both heart beat intervals and respiration cycles.

 

From a broader impacts perspective, the EasySense device has since been deployed in congestive heart failure (CHF) patients to detect early signs of fluid accumulation in their lungs. Pilot data with 20 patients shows the potential to reduce readmission in CHF patients and field study with 75 patients is being conducted. The project trained several graduate students at Ohio State (including a female student) in the design of ultra-wide band radio frequency sensors in a mobile form factor. It also helped train several graduate students at Memphis (including another female student) on analysis of physiological data to develop computational models for detecting human health and daily behaviors from mobile sensor data collected in the natural field environment. Graduate students working on the project obtained faculty positions and industry research positions at IBM Research and Samsung Research.
